title: Revealing Laser Interactions with Thin Films Using In Situ Methods
content: Additive manufacturing is becoming a decisive technology for structural materials in a wide range of applications including nuclear, naval, aerospace, electronic devices, land transportation, and even in jewelry and art decorations [1-5]. The prospect of on-the-fly fabrication of materials, tailored to meet specific component requirements, holds considerable allure. Nevertheless, there is currently insufficient in situ experimental data to capture material interaction at nano- and atomic-scale levels, hindering the enhancement of exciting models and simulations for seamless direct fabrication of the components. This gap obstructs detailed investigations into solidification and solid-state phase transformations occurring during and after laser beam interactions. In our research, we employed in situ laser system integrated into both a secondary electron microscope (SEM) and scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) to explore the formation of non-equilibrium phase transformations and their evolution during in situ laser beam interaction with Fe-Cr-Ni structural material at multiscale level (µm-nm-Å).
